awd_titl_txt: Postdoctoral Fellowship: MPS-Ascend: Photoactive Metal-organic Nanocages for Sequestration and Degradation of Poly- and Perfluoroalkyl Substances
awd_abstract_narration:
Karla Rosalia Sanchez Lievanos is awarded an NSF Mathematical and Physical Sciences Ascending Postdoctoral Research Fellowship (NSF MPS-Ascend) to conduct a program of research and activities related to broaden participation by groups underrepresented in STEM. This fellowship to Dr. Sanchez Lievanos supports the research project entitled “MPS-Ascend: Photoactive Metal-organic Nanocages for Sequestration and Degradation of Poly- and Perfluoroalkyl Substances” under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The host institution for the fellowship is the State University of New York at Buffalo, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Diana S. Aga.           

This proposal aims to utilize inorganic chemistry design principles to generate a safe prototype technology to remediate water pollution caused by ubiquitous and persistent poly and perfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS). The proposed work will develop robust porous and photoactive molecular nanocages with potential chemical affinity and catalytic activity for selective sequestration and photo-degradation of PFAS. The work will focus on studying the binding interactions between the nanocages and PFAS, evaluating the photo-induced reactivity of the nanocages to generate reactive oxygen species for PFAS decomposition, developing a mechanism of photo-degradation, and performing ecotoxicology studies on selected nanocages as part of a safe-by-design strategy for potential scale-up. Successful implementation of this work may allow for the development of functional materials that reliably and safely remove PFAS from water.

The PI intends to establish a partnership with the Buffalo Public School system to develop efficient tools to improve educational efficiency in underperforming Community Schools. The PI will join the Buffalo Niagara Waterkeeper organization to offer seminars to underrepresented minority groups on water quality issues and remediation efforts. The PI will also partner with the International Younger Chemist Network to increase global participation in developing and understanding water remediation technologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The State University of New York at Buffalo

por.por_cntn:
Water contamination by harmful chemicals, particularly per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS), poses serious risks to human health and the environment. This project explored the use of small, structured materials called nanocages to selectively capture and remove PFAS from contaminated water. These nanocages offer a promising solution for water remediation, combining high efficiency, reusability, and environmental safety.

Our research successfully developed and tested nanocages that demonstrated potential for PFAS removal. These materials were synthesized using efficient one-pot processes and tested across different water sources, including sewage and groundwater. Importantly, the nanocages remained stable under a wide range of conditions, making them well-suited for environmental applications. Tests showed that they could remove over 90% of PFAS from clean water and groundwater and approximately 80% from more complex environments like sewage. The nanocages also worked significantly faster than traditional filtration methods, reaching peak efficiency within just 15 minutes. Unlike existing approaches, these nanocages maintained their performance across multiple reuse cycles, making them a potentially cost-effective solution for water treatment. In addition to performance testing, we investigated how these nanocages interact with PFAS at the molecular level. Results indicated that their unique structure allows them to attract and trap certain types of PFAS more effectively than others, particularly those commonly found in industrial sites and landfills. Early ecotoxicity tests confirmed that the nanocages pose minimal environmental risks at potential leaching levels, further supporting their suitability for safe, large-scale implementation.

Beyond laboratory research, this project actively engaged local communities to raise awareness about PFAS and water contamination. We partnered with Buffalo Niagara Waterkeeper (BNWK) to provide local fishing communities with safe fishing and consumption guidance. Identifying additional language needs through outreach efforts, we expanded and updated translations of outreach materials for Spanish, Pashto, and Bengali speakers. Moreover, we participated in and planned educational outreach activities for middle school students in BNWK programs, engaging them in hands-on water sampling and other water-related events to enhance their understanding of water chemistry and quality. Additionally, we hosted webinars featuring experts from various fields to discuss PFAS regulation, removal technologies, and health impacts (free access: https://www.pfasfutureleaders.org/). To support early-career scientists, we secured membership waivers for graduate students to join professional scientific organizations in exchange for creating three-minute videos about their research, helping them gain global exposure and improve science communication skills.

This project has made meaningful contributions to advancing safer, more effectivePFAS remediation materials while fostering community involvement in environmental protection and advocacy. Integrating these materials into existing treatment technologies could significantly reduce PFAS exposure and improve water quality and safety.


Last Modified: 02/28/2025
Modified by: Karla Rosalia Sanchez Lievanos
